issues.title: Evaluate RyuGraph as Kuzu replacement for graph database
issues.body:
## Background

Kuzu (our current embedded graph database) was **archived on October 10, 2025** and is no longer maintained. RyuGraph is an actively maintained fork that continues development.

## Current State
- Using Kuzu v0.11.3 (final release)
- Required subprocess isolation to work around threading issues with LanceDB
- Kuzu won't receive bug fixes or improvements

## RyuGraph Overview
- Fork of Kuzu by Predictable Labs
- Current version: v25.9.2 (Dec 2025)
- PyPI: `pip install ryugraph`
- Added features: built-in vector indexing, native full-text search
- API-compatible with Kuzu (should be drop-in replacement)

## Why Defer?
- RyuGraph's vector search lacks column size optimization for large volumes
- LanceDB remains better for our vector storage needs
- Current workaround (subprocess isolation) is functional

## Future Evaluation Criteria
1. Does RyuGraph fix threading issues with PyO3?
2. Performance comparison with Kuzu
3. Stability of the project under new maintainers
4. If vector optimization improves, could consolidate LanceDB + graph DB

## References
- RyuGraph: https://github.com/predictable-labs/ryugraph
- Kuzu archive notice: https://github.com/kuzudb/kuzu

issues.title: feat: Add temporal knowledge graph with git-based versioning
issues.body:
## Summary
Build a temporal knowledge graph that tracks entity and relationship changes over time using git history.

## Background
Current indexing is point-in-time. A temporal KG enables:
- "What called function X before commit Y?"
- "When was this relationship introduced?"
- "How has this module's dependencies evolved?"

## Architecture
- Graph storage: Kuzu (already integrated via kuzu-memory)
- Temporal model: Entity versions linked to git commits
- Background processing: Hook into existing file watcher

## Schema
```
Entity(id, name, type, file_path)
EntityVersion(entity_id, commit_sha, timestamp, content_hash)
Relationship(source_id, target_id, type, valid_from, valid_to)
```

## Tasks
- [ ] Design Kuzu schema for temporal entities/relationships
- [ ] Implement git commit integration (extract SHA, timestamp)
- [ ] Background graph builder (hook into file watcher)
- [ ] Temporal query API (as-of queries)
- [ ] MCP tools: query_graph, get_entity_history, find_relationships

## Dependencies
- Depends on: Performance optimization ticket (entity extraction)
- Depends on: NLP ticket (unified entity model)

## Success Criteria
- Entities tracked across commits
- Relationships have valid_from/valid_to timestamps
- Query "what called X before commit Y" works

issues.title: feat: Add NLP entity extraction from docstrings and comments
issues.body:
## Summary
Add NLP-based entity and concept extraction from docstrings, comments, and documentation to complement AST-based structural extraction.

## Background
AST gives us structural relationships (calls, imports, inheritance). NLP on text content gives us semantic relationships (concepts, topics, domain terms).

## Approach (No LLM required)
- YAKE for keyword extraction (fast, unsupervised)
- spaCy for NER and dependency parsing
- Existing sentence-transformers for similarity

## Tasks
- [ ] Add yake and spacy dependencies
- [ ] Extract keywords from docstrings using YAKE
- [ ] Extract named entities from comments using spaCy
- [ ] Link NLP entities to AST entities via proximity/embedding similarity
- [ ] Unified entity model (source: ast | nlp | both)

## Dependencies
- Depends on: Performance optimization ticket (entity extraction foundation)

## Success Criteria
- Domain concepts extracted from docstrings
- Cross-references between code entities and documentation
- Query: "find code related to authentication" returns both AST and doc matches

issues.title: TLS certificate bundle error: Python version mismatch (3.13 vs 3.12)
issues.body:
## Bug Description

mcp-vector-search MCP tools fail with TLS certificate error due to Python version mismatch.

## Error

```
Failed to load embedding model: Could not find a suitable TLS CA certificate bundle, invalid path: /Users/masa/.local/share/uv/tools/mcp-vector-search/lib/python3.13/site-packages/certifi/cacert.pem
```

## Root Cause

The tool is installed with Python 3.12:
```
/Users/masa/.local/share/uv/tools/mcp-vector-search/lib/python3.12/site-packages/certifi/cacert.pem  # EXISTS
```

But the MCP server process is spawned with system Python 3.13:
```
/opt/homebrew/Cellar/python@3.13/3.13.11_1/.../Python /Users/masa/.local/bin/mcp-vector-search mcp
```

This causes the certifi path lookup to fail because it looks in python3.13 directory which doesn't exist.

## Expected Behavior

MCP server should use the same Python environment as the tool installation, not the system Python.

## Environment

- mcp-vector-search version: 2.2.21
- Python tool version: 3.12 (uv tools)
- System Python: 3.13 (homebrew)
- OS: macOS

## Workaround

Unknown - may need to restart Claude Code session or force the correct Python.

issues.title: Add /wiki command with ontology navigation
issues.body:
## Feature: Wiki Command with Ontology Navigation

### Description
Add a `/wiki` command that creates an ontology map of the codebase knowledge base with tree-style navigation and intelligent semantic grouping.

### Requirements

#### Core Functionality
1. **Ontology Generation**: Extract top-level concepts from indexed chunks and organize into hierarchical tree structure
2. **Tree Navigation**: Display top-level concepts with expandable links to child concepts
3. **Concept Descriptions**: Show clear descriptions for each concept node
4. **LLM-Powered Semantic Grouping**: Uses LLM to intelligently combine chunks based on semantic relationships (requires LLM connection)
5. **JSON Output**: Results delivered as structured JSON for programmatic access
6. **Caching System**: Cached with configurable TTL (default 24 hours)
7. **Static Site Generation**: `--display` option generates HTML wiki with elegant CSS styling (cached)

### Technical Implementation Notes

- **LLM Integration**: Requires LLM connection for semantic grouping and intelligent chunk combination
- **Storage Backend**: Leverage existing chunk storage (LanceDB) for efficient retrieval
- **Cache Strategy**: 
  - Default TTL: 24 hours
  - Cache invalidation on re-index operations
  - Store both JSON and HTML outputs separately
- **HTML Generation**: 
  - Clean semantic markup (HTML5)
  - Responsive CSS design
  - Tree navigation with expand/collapse
  - Search functionality within wiki

### Usage Examples

```bash
# Generate JSON ontology
mcp-vector-search /wiki

# Generate and display HTML wiki
mcp-vector-search /wiki --display

# Configure cache TTL
mcp-vector-search /wiki --ttl 48h
```

### Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `/wiki` command generates JSON ontology structure
- [ ] Tree structure properly represents parent/child concept relationships
- [ ] LLM intelligently combines related chunks based on semantic similarity
- [ ] Configurable TTL caching system implemented
- [ ] `--display` flag generates static HTML wiki site
- [ ] CSS styling is clean, elegant, and responsive
- [ ] Works seamlessly with MCP server integration
- [ ] Cache invalidates correctly on re-index
- [ ] Documentation updated with usage examples
- [ ] Unit tests cover core ontology generation logic
- [ ] Integration tests verify LLM-powered grouping

### Related Components

- Existing chunk storage (LanceDB)
- LLM integration layer
- CLI command interface
- MCP server endpoints

### Priority

Medium - Enhances codebase exploration and knowledge discovery

issues.title: Bug: 'CodeBERTEmbeddingFunction' object has no attribute 'embed_query'
issues.body:
## Description

When running search queries, the mcp-vector-search library fails with:

```
'CodeBERTEmbeddingFunction' object has no attribute 'embed_query' in query.
```

## Environment

- **mcp-vector-search version**: 2.2+
- **Deployment**: AWS ECS Fargate
- **Python**: 3.11

## Error Logs

```
2026-02-11 02:23:11.147 | WARNING  | mcp_vector_search.core.search:_perform_health_check:336 - Database health check failed - attempting recovery
2026-02-11 02:23:11.148 | ERROR    | mcp_vector_search.core.search_handler:execute_search:53 - Search failed: 'CodeBERTEmbeddingFunction' object has no attribute 'embed_query' in query.
2026-02-11 02:23:11.148 | ERROR    | mcp_vector_search.core.search_retry_handler:search_with_retry:157 - Search failed: Search failed: 'CodeBERTEmbeddingFunction' object has no attribute 'embed_query' in query.
```

Additional warning before the error:
```
2026-02-11 02:23:11.151 | WARNING  | mcp_vector_search.core.embeddings:create_embedding_function:697 - Model 'microsoft/codebert-base' is deprecated. Automatically using 'Salesforce/SFR-Embedding-Code-400M_R' instead.
2026-02-11 02:23:11.311 | WARNING  | mcp_vector_search.core.embeddings:create_embedding_function:713 - Failed to create ChromaDB embedding function: Alibaba-NLP/new-impl You can inspect the repository content at https://hf.co/Salesforce/SFR-Embedding-Code-400M_R.
Please pass the argument trust_remote_code=True to allow custom code to be run.
```

## Root Cause Analysis

1. The library tries to use `microsoft/codebert-base` but it's deprecated
2. Falls back to `Salesforce/SFR-Embedding-Code-400M_R` but fails to create ChromaDB embedding function
3. Falls back to `CodeBERTEmbeddingFunction` which doesn't have the `embed_query` method required by the search handler

## Expected Behavior

Search should work with the fallback embedding function, or provide a clear error about which embedding model to use.

## Suggested Fix

1. Ensure `CodeBERTEmbeddingFunction` implements `embed_query()` method
2. Or update the embedding function creation to properly handle the `trust_remote_code=True` requirement for newer models
3. Or provide configuration to explicitly set a working embedding model

## Workaround

None currently - search is completely broken.

issues.title: feat: Two-phase indexing with durable chunks and incremental updates
issues.body:
## Summary
Refactor indexing pipeline to separate parsing/chunking from embedding generation, enabling resumable operations, incremental updates, and better resource utilization.

## Current Behavior
- Single pipeline: Parse â†’ Chunk â†’ Embed â†’ Write
- No persistence between stages
- Must re-process everything if interrupted
- No incremental updates (always full re-index)

## Proposed Architecture

### Phase 1: Parse & Chunk (Fast, Durable)
```
File â†’ [Hash Check] â†’ [Parse AST] â†’ [Chunk] â†’ chunks.lance
```
- Store parsed chunks durably before embedding
- Include file_hash for change detection
- Skip unchanged files on re-run
- Completes in minutes for large codebases

### Phase 2: Embed (Batch, Resumable)
```
chunks.lance â†’ [Find unembedded] â†’ [Embed] â†’ vectors.lance
```
- Separate batch process
- Can run as daemon, scheduled job, or on-demand
- Parallelizable across workers
- Resume from where it left off

### CLI Commands
```bash
mcp-vector-search chunk [--force] [--changed-only]  # Phase 1
mcp-vector-search embed [--batch-size N] [--workers N]  # Phase 2
mcp-vector-search index  # Combined (current behavior)
mcp-vector-search status  # Show chunks vs embedded counts
```

## Benefits
- **Resumable**: Embedding can resume after crash/interrupt
- **Incremental**: Only re-process changed files
- **Faster feedback**: See parsed results before embedding completes
- **Better parallelism**: Embedding workers can scale independently
- **Resource efficient**: Parse on CPU, embed on GPU/API separately

## Implementation Tasks
- [ ] Create `chunks.lance` schema (no embeddings)
- [ ] Add file_hash tracking for change detection
- [ ] Implement `chunk` CLI command
- [ ] Implement `embed` CLI command with batch processing
- [ ] Add `status` command showing pipeline state
- [ ] Update `index` to use two-phase internally
- [ ] Add stale chunk cleanup (deleted files)
- [ ] Documentation

## Technical Notes
- Use separate LanceDB tables: `chunks` (raw) and `vectors` (embedded)
- File hash: SHA-256 of content
- Change detection: compare hash + mtime
- Embedding queue: track `embedded_at` timestamp per chunk

issues.title: Detect internal HNSW graph corruption during initialization
issues.body:
## Problem

When ChromaDB's HNSW index has internal graph corruption, mcp-vector-search fails to detect it during initialization. The corruption only manifests when performing DELETE operations, causing 100% indexing failure rate.

### Error observed:
```
ERROR: Failed to collect database statistics: Error executing plan: 
Error sending backfill request to compactor: Error constructing hnsw segment reader: 
Error creating hnsw segment reader: Error loading hnsw index
```

### Current behavior:
- v1.2.9 added corruption recovery that checks for:
  - Empty files
  - Truncated files  
  - All-zero files
- **Gap**: Doesn't validate internal HNSW graph structure
- Corruption only detected during DELETE operations (too late)

### Expected behavior:
- Detect HNSW corruption during database initialization
- Automatically trigger recovery/rebuild when corruption detected
- Log clear message: "HNSW index corrupted, rebuilding..."

### Reproduction:
1. Index a large project (700+ files)
2. Kill indexing process with `kill -9` mid-operation
3. Attempt to reindex â†’ 100% failure rate

### Workaround:
```bash
mcp-vector-search reset index
mcp-vector-search index
```

### Suggested fix:
Add a lightweight HNSW health check during `ChromaDBManager` initialization:
- Attempt a test query (e.g., get first chunk)
- If HNSW error occurs, trigger automatic recovery
- This catches corruption before user operations fail

## Related
- Follow-up to v1.2.9 corruption detection improvements
- Addresses silent corruption failures in production use

issues.title: fix: use node.text for chunk_id hash instead of full line range
issues.body:
## Problem
When multiple functions on the same line have the same name AND same content, their chunk_id is still identical, causing "Expected IDs to be unique" errors.

Current code uses `self._get_line_range(lines, start_line, end_line)` which extracts entire lines from start to end. When functions share the same line range, the hash is identical.

## Solution
Change to `content = node.text.decode()` so the content hash is based on the actual function code, not the line range.

## Benefits
1. **Unique chunk_ids**: Each function has different actual code, even on the same line
2. **Efficiency**: Instead of storing 16KB per chunk (5 functions Ã— 16KB = 80KB), stores only actual function code (~700 bytes total)

## Files to Change
- `src/mcp_vector_search/core/database.py` or relevant parser file where `_get_line_range` is used for content hashing

issues.title: feat: CodeXEmbed integration for improved code search accuracy
issues.body:
## Summary
Integrate `Salesforce/SFR-Embedding-Code-400M_R` (CodeXEmbed-400M) as the default embedding model for 25-28% better code search accuracy.

## Current Status
- Performance optimizations committed (HNSW tuning, GPU support, etc.)
- Migration system implemented and ready
- CodeXEmbed requires additional integration work

## Issues to Fix

### 1. trust_remote_code Requirement
CodeXEmbed uses custom code from Alibaba-NLP and requires `trust_remote_code=True`:
```python
SentenceTransformer(model_name, trust_remote_code=True)
```
**Status**: âœ… Fixed in embeddings.py

### 2. Dimension Mismatch
- Documented as 768 dimensions
- Actual output: 1024 dimensions
**Status**: âœ… Fixed in defaults.py MODEL_SPECIFICATIONS

### 3. ChromaDB Embedding Function Conflict
When ChromaDB creates collections, it tries to create its own embedding function wrapper which fails:
```
WARNING: Failed to create ChromaDB embedding function: Alibaba-NLP/new-impl
```
This causes an embedding function conflict when reopening collections.

**Needs Investigation**: How to properly pass embedding function to ChromaDB with trust_remote_code models.

## Alternative: GraphCodeBERT
Research found `microsoft/graphcodebert-base` works without trust_remote_code:
- 768 dimensions
- Code-specific (pre-trained on 6 languages)
- Works with standard sentence-transformers

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] CodeXEmbed loads and generates embeddings correctly
- [ ] ChromaDB collection creation works without conflicts
- [ ] Existing indexes can be migrated automatically
- [ ] Fallback to legacy model if CodeXEmbed fails
- [ ] OR: Switch to GraphCodeBERT as the code-specific model

## Related
- Migration system: v1.2.2 migration already prepared
- Performance optimizations: Committed in 7d1db70

issues.title: feat: Add dead code analysis command (`analyze dead-code`)
issues.body:
## Summary
Add a `dead-code` subcommand to the `analyze` CLI that identifies potentially unreachable code using AST-based call graph analysis and entry point detection.

**Suggested Labels**: `enhancement`, `analysis`, `good first issue`

## Background
The codebase already has 90% of the required infrastructure:
- âœ… AST-based call extraction (`extract_function_calls()` in `relationships.py`)
- âœ… Graph traversal algorithms (`CircularDependencyDetector` DFS)
- âœ… Code smell framework (`SmellDetector`)
- âœ… Multi-format output (JSON, SARIF, Markdown)
- âœ… Visualization hints (D3.js red borders)

## Requirements

### 1. Entry Point Detection
Automatically detect entry points:
- `if __name__ == "__main__":` blocks
- CLI decorators (`@click.command`, `@app.command`)
- FastAPI/Flask routes (`@app.get`, `@router.post`)
- Pytest functions (`test_*`, `@pytest.fixture`)
- `__all__` exports in `__init__.py`
- Public module-level functions (configurable)

### 2. Reachability Analysis
- Build callerâ†’callee inverted call graph
- BFS/DFS from all entry points
- Mark all reachable functions
- Report unreachable functions as "dead code"

### 3. Confidence Levels
Reduce false positive noise with confidence scoring:
- **HIGH**: Private functions (`_name`) with no callers
- **MEDIUM**: Public functions with no callers
- **LOW**: Functions that might be dynamically called (decorator patterns, `getattr`)

### 4. False Positive Mitigation
Handle common patterns that cause false positives:
- Dynamic dispatch (`getattr`, `__getattribute__`)
- Decorator-registered handlers
- String-based imports (`importlib.import_module`)
- Reflection patterns
- Abstract methods / interface implementations

### 5. CLI Interface
```bash
# Basic usage
mcp-vector-search analyze dead-code

# Custom entry points
mcp-vector-search analyze dead-code --entry-point "src/main.py:main"

# Filter by confidence
mcp-vector-search analyze dead-code --min-confidence high

# CI/CD mode
mcp-vector-search analyze dead-code --fail-on-dead --output sarif

# Exclude patterns
mcp-vector-search analyze dead-code --exclude "**/tests/**" --exclude "**/_*.py"
```

### 6. Output Formats
- **Console**: Human-readable with colors
- **JSON**: Machine-parseable for tooling
- **SARIF**: GitHub Code Scanning integration
- **Markdown**: Documentation/reports

## Example Output
```
Dead Code Analysis Report
â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•â•

Entry Points Detected: 5
  â€¢ main() in main.py (MAIN)
  â€¢ cli() in cli.py (CLI)  
  â€¢ test_integration() in tests/test_api.py (TEST)

Dead Code Findings: 12

[HIGH CONFIDENCE] (7 findings)
  â€¢ _legacy_converter in utils/converters.py:45-67
    Reason: Private function, no incoming calls

[MEDIUM CONFIDENCE] (5 findings)  
  â€¢ public_utility in utils/misc.py:89-102
    Reason: No incoming calls
    Caveat: Public function (might be API)

Summary:
  Total Functions: 245
  Reachable: 233 (95.1%)
  Unreachable: 12 (4.9%)
```

## Technical Approach

### Files to Create/Modify
- `src/mcp_vector_search/analysis/dead_code.py` (NEW)
- `src/mcp_vector_search/analysis/entry_points.py` (NEW)

@dataclass
class EntryPoint:

issues.title: Exclude ALL dot directories by default (prevent 2TB+ indexes)
issues.body:
## Problem

The default ignore patterns only excluded **specific** dot directories (`.git`, `.vscode`, `.mypy_cache`, etc.) rather than ALL dot directories. This caused massive 2TB+ indexes when projects contained large framework directories like:

- `.next` (Next.js build cache)
- `.turbo` (Turborepo cache)
- `.parcel-cache` (Parcel bundler)
- `.vite` (Vite build cache)
- And any custom dot directories

## Solution

**Commit:** 7a98836

1. Added `".*"` wildcard pattern as the **FIRST entry** in `DEFAULT_IGNORE_PATTERNS`
2. Implemented `fnmatch` support in the indexer for wildcard pattern matching
3. `ALLOWED_DOTFILES` whitelist (`.github`, `.circleci`, `.gitlab-ci`) is still respected

## Changes

- `src/mcp_vector_search/config/defaults.py`: Added `".*"` pattern with documentation
- `src/mcp_vector_search/core/indexer.py`: Added fnmatch import and wildcard matching logic

## Behavior

| Pattern | Before | After |
|---------|--------|-------|
| `.next/cache/file.js` | âœ… INDEXED | ðŸš« IGNORED |
| `.turbo/build/out.js` | âœ… INDEXED | ðŸš« IGNORED |
| `.custom-tool/data.txt` | âœ… INDEXED | ðŸš« IGNORED |
| `.github/workflows/ci.yml` | âœ… INDEXED | âœ… INDEXED (whitelisted) |
| `src/main.py` | âœ… INDEXED | âœ… INDEXED |

## Testing

```bash
# All pass
fnmatch(".next", ".*")        â†’ True âœ…
fnmatch(".turbo", ".*")       â†’ True âœ…
fnmatch("node_modules", ".*") â†’ False âœ…
fnmatch("src", ".*")          â†’ False âœ…
```

All pre-commit hooks (black, ruff, mypy, bandit) passed.

issues.title: Add timeout and deadlock protection for indexing operations
issues.body:
## Problem

Indexing large repositories can get stuck indefinitely with no recovery mechanism. Observed during indexing of a 24k+ file repository where the process deadlocked at 48% completion.

## Symptoms Observed

- Process at 0% CPU (sleeping, not processing)
- SQLite journal file indicating incomplete transaction
- CLOSE_WAIT socket to embedding API (stale connection)
- No file modifications for 15+ minutes
- Stuck on a tiny 14-line file (not a file size issue)
- Required manual `kill` and journal cleanup to recover

## Root Causes

1. **No timeout on embedding API calls** - Can wait forever if API hangs
2. **No transaction timeout** - SQLite operations can deadlock
3. **No progress heartbeat** - No detection of stalled processing
4. **Poor connection cleanup** - Sockets left in CLOSE_WAIT state
5. **No checkpoint/resume** - Must restart from beginning after crash

## Proposed Solutions

### 1. Embedding API Timeouts (HIGH PRIORITY)
```python
# Add timeout to embedding calls
async with asyncio.timeout(30):  # 30 second timeout per batch
    embeddings = await model.encode(chunks)
```

### 2. Progress Heartbeat
```python
# If no progress for N minutes, log warning and optionally abort
HEARTBEAT_TIMEOUT = 300  # 5 minutes
last_progress = time.time()

def on_file_indexed():
    global last_progress
    last_progress = time.time()

def check_heartbeat():
    if time.time() - last_progress > HEARTBEAT_TIMEOUT:
        logger.error("No progress for 5 minutes - possible deadlock")
        # Optionally: raise DeadlockDetectedError()
```

### 3. SQLite Transaction Timeouts
```python
# Add busy_timeout to prevent indefinite waits
connection.execute("PRAGMA busy_timeout = 30000")  # 30 seconds
```

### 4. Graceful Connection Cleanup
```python
# Ensure connections are properly closed
try:
    result = await api_call()
finally:
    await connection.close()
```

### 5. Checkpoint/Resume (NICE TO HAVE)
```python
# Save progress to resume after interruption
checkpoint = {
    "last_indexed_file": current_file,
    "files_completed": count,
    "timestamp": datetime.now()
}
save_checkpoint(checkpoint)
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Embedding API calls have configurable timeout (default 30s)
- [ ] SQLite connections have busy_timeout set
- [ ] Progress heartbeat logs warning if stalled > 5 minutes
- [ ] Stale journal files are cleaned up on startup
- [ ] Connections are properly closed in finally blocks
- [ ] (Optional) Checkpoint/resume for large repositories

## Workaround

Manual recovery:
```bash
kill <pid>
rm .mcp-vector-search/chroma.sqlite3-journal
mcp-vector-search index
```

## Context

Occurred during indexing of `~/Clients/Duetto/CTO` with 24,513 files. Process deadlocked after indexing 11,790 files (48%).

issues.title: `init --force` doesn't update extensions to new defaults
issues.body:
## Problem

When running `mcp-vector-search init --force` on an existing project, the config file retains old extension values instead of being regenerated with current defaults (71 extensions as of v1.1.24).

## Steps to Reproduce

```bash
# Project initialized with old version (e.g., v1.1.22)
# Config has: .json, .md, .sh

# Upgrade to v1.1.24
pipx upgrade mcp-vector-search

# Try to reinitialize
mcp-vector-search init --force

# Check indexing - still shows old extensions
mcp-vector-search index --force
# Output: "File extensions: .json, .md, .sh"  â† Should be 71 extensions
```

## Expected Behavior

`init --force` should:
1. Regenerate `.mcp-vector-search/config.json` with current `DEFAULT_FILE_EXTENSIONS`
2. User shouldn't need to manually delete config directory

## Current Workaround

```bash
rm -rf .mcp-vector-search/
mcp-vector-search init
```

## Root Cause Investigation Needed

Check `cli/commands/init.py` and `core/project.py`:
- Does `--force` actually regenerate config from defaults?
- Or does it just allow overwriting while preserving old values?

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `init --force` regenerates config with current defaults
- [ ] Existing custom settings (non-default) should prompt for confirmation before overwriting
- [ ] Add test case for this scenario

issues.title: Default to indexing all supported code extensions
issues.body:
## Problem

Currently users must specify `--extensions .py,.js,.ts,...` to index code. This is backwards - the tool should index all supported code by default and only require `--extensions` to **limit** scope.

## Current Behavior
```bash
mcp-vector-search init
# Only indexes: .json, .md, .sh (or similar minimal set)

mcp-vector-search init --extensions .py,.js,.ts
# Indexes specified extensions
```

## Expected Behavior
```bash
mcp-vector-search init
# Indexes ALL supported code extensions automatically:
# .py, .js, .ts, .tsx, .jsx, .java, .go, .rs, .rb, .php, .dart, .c, .cpp, .h, .cs, .swift, .kt, .scala, .sh, .json, .yaml, .yml, .md, .html, .css

mcp-vector-search init --extensions .py,.js
# LIMITS to only Python and JavaScript (filter mode)
```

## Supported Languages (from parsers)

Full Tree-Sitter support:
- Python: `.py`, `.pyw`
- JavaScript: `.js`, `.jsx`, `.mjs`
- TypeScript: `.ts`, `.tsx`
- Dart: `.dart`
- PHP: `.php`
- Ruby: `.rb`
- HTML: `.html`
- Text/Docs: `.txt`, `.md`

Fallback support (line-based):
- Java: `.java`
- C/C++: `.c`, `.cpp`, `.h`, `.hpp`
- C#: `.cs`
- Go: `.go`
- Rust: `.rs`
- Swift: `.swift`
- Kotlin: `.kt`
- Scala: `.scala`
- Shell: `.sh`, `.bash`
- Config: `.json`, `.yaml`, `.yml`, `.toml`

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `mcp-vector-search init` with no flags indexes all supported extensions
- [ ] `--extensions` flag becomes a **filter** to limit scope
- [ ] Update CLI help text to reflect new behavior
- [ ] Update documentation

## Context

Users deploying to large repos with `./repos` subdirectories expect the tool to find all code automatically. Current behavior requires manual extension specification, which defeats "just works" UX.

issues.title: Add background indexing mode with progress tracking
issues.body:
## Overview

Add `--background` flag to the index command to allow non-blocking indexing operations. Store progress in a JSON file and provide a status command to check indexing progress.

**Parent Epic**: #67

## Current Problem

- `mcp-vs index` blocks for 4-8 minutes with large codebases
- No way to monitor long-running indexing operations
- Cannot continue working while indexing is in progress

## Proposed Solution

Add background processing mode with progress tracking:

### 1. Background Flag
```bash
mcp-vs index --background
# Output: Indexing started in background (PID: 12345)
# Check progress with: mcp-vs status
```

### 2. Progress Tracking
Store progress in `.mcp-vector-search/index-progress.json`:
```json
{
  "status": "running",
  "pid": 12345,
  "started_at": "2025-12-20T22:00:00Z",
  "phase": "computing_relationships",
  "progress": {
    "current": 15000,
    "total": 26000,
    "percentage": 57.7
  },
  "last_updated": "2025-12-20T22:05:00Z"
}
```

### 3. Status Command
```bash
mcp-vs status
# Output:
# Indexing Status: Running
# Phase: Computing relationships (57.7% complete)
# Processed: 15,000 / 26,000 chunks
# Elapsed: 5m 23s
# PID: 12345
```

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `mcp-vs index --background` spawns detached process
- [ ] Background process writes PID and progress to `.mcp-vector-search/index-progress.json`
- [ ] `mcp-vs status` command shows current indexing progress
- [ ] Status command handles cases: not running, running, completed, error
- [ ] Clean completion handling (remove progress file on success)
- [ ] Error handling (store error details in progress file)
- [ ] Process cleanup on interruption (SIGTERM/SIGINT)
- [ ] Tests for background mode and status command
- [ ] Documentation for background indexing workflow

## Technical Implementation

### Background Process Spawning
- Use `subprocess.Popen()` with detached mode
- Redirect stdout/stderr to log file
- Store PID for process management

### Progress Persistence
- Atomic writes to progress file
- File locking to prevent race conditions
- Regular update interval (every 1-2 seconds)

### Status Command
- Read progress file
- Verify process is still running (check PID)
- Format and display progress information
- Handle stale progress files (process died)

## User Experience

**Starting background indexing:**
```bash
$ mcp-vs index --background
âœ“ Indexing started in background (PID: 12345)
  Log file: .mcp-vector-search/index.log
  Check progress: mcp-vs status
```

**Checking status:**
```bash
$ mcp-vs status
Indexing Status: Running
Phase: Computing relationships
Progress: 15,000 / 26,000 chunks (57.7%)
Elapsed: 5m 23s
Estimated remaining: 3m 45s
```

**When complete:**
```bash
$ mcp-vs status
No indexing operation in progress.
Last indexed: 2025-12-20 22:10:00 (5 minutes ago)
```

## Error Handling

- Process crash: Detect via PID check, report error
- Partial completion: Store error details in progress file
- User interruption: Clean shutdown, update progress file with "cancelled" status
- File permission issues: Clear error messages

## Testing Strategy

1. Unit tests for progress file read/write
2. Integration tests for background process spawning
3. Status command tests with various states
4. Error handling tests (process crash, interruption)
5. Manual testing for user experience validation

issues.title: Implement async parallel relationship computation
issues.body:
## Overview

Replace the sequential loop in `relationships.py:204-294` with async parallel processing using `asyncio.gather()` and semaphore for concurrent database queries. This should achieve 3-5x speedup for semantic relationship computation.

**Parent Epic**: #67

## Current Implementation

The current code processes chunks sequentially:
```python
# relationships.py:204-294
for chunk in chunks:
    # Process each chunk one at a time
    # Database query for relationships
    # ~50-100 chunks/second
```

## Proposed Solution

Implement async parallel processing:
- Use `asyncio.gather()` for concurrent chunk processing
- Add semaphore to control concurrency level (configurable, default: 10-20)
- Maintain existing progress tracking callback mechanism
- Ensure thread-safe database access

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Replace sequential loop with async parallel implementation
- [ ] Add configurable concurrency control (semaphore)
- [ ] Progress tracking callback works correctly with parallel execution
- [ ] Results match sequential version (validate with test suite)
- [ ] Add unit tests for parallel computation
- [ ] Add integration tests comparing sequential vs parallel results
- [ ] Performance tests showing 3-5x speedup
- [ ] Documentation updated with concurrency configuration options

## Technical Considerations

- **Database access**: Ensure ChromaDB client is thread-safe or use connection pooling
- **Memory usage**: Monitor memory consumption with concurrent operations
- **Error handling**: Propagate errors correctly from parallel tasks
- **Progress accuracy**: Update progress atomically from concurrent tasks

## Expected Performance

- **Current**: 50-100 chunks/second (sequential)
- **Target**: 200-500 chunks/second (parallel with concurrency=10-20)
- **Impact**: 4-8 minute indexing â†’ 1-2 minutes for 26K chunks

## Testing Strategy

1. Unit tests for async computation logic
2. Integration tests comparing results with sequential version
3. Performance benchmarks with different concurrency levels
4. Edge case testing (errors, empty results, etc.)

Tree-sitter parsing is CPU-bound but runs single-threaded. `asyncio.gather()` provides NO parallelism for CPU work.

issues.title: perf: Enable TOKENIZERS_PARALLELISM with process detection guard
issues.body:
## Problem
`TOKENIZERS_PARALLELISM` is set to "false" in `embeddings.py` line 10 as defensive programming to avoid fork issues. This causes 2-4x slowdown for embedding generation.

## Solution
Add process detection guard to safely enable parallel tokenization:
- Check if we're in main process vs forked process
- Only enable parallelism in main process
- Disable before any multiprocessing operations

## Impact: 2-4x speedup for embeddings

issues.title: Phase 5: Performance optimization, LOD, and accessibility
issues.body:
## Parent Issue
Part of #51 - Enhanced D3.js Code Quality Visualization Dashboard

## Objective
Optimize the visualization for large codebases, add responsive design, and ensure accessibility compliance.

## Deliverables

// Simplify rendering based on zoom level
const lodScale = d3.scaleThreshold()
  .domain([0.3, 0.6, 1.0])

### 2. Module Aggregation (>200 files)

issues.title: feat(visualization): Enhanced D3.js Code Quality Visualization Dashboard
issues.body:
## Problem Statement

The mcp-vector-search project has comprehensive structural analysis capabilities (v0.21.0+) that generate rich metrics data, but the current visualization tool doesn't fully leverage this data to provide **immediate visual understanding** of code quality. Users need to parse textual metrics and tables to identify:

- Quality hotspots requiring immediate attention
- Architectural weaknesses (high coupling, circular dependencies)
- Code health trends and distribution
- Refactoring priorities across large codebases

**Current gaps:**
- No visual encoding of complexity grades (A-F) or health scores
- Limited indication of code smell severity (info/warning/error)
- Dependency graphs don't show coupling strength or instability
- No spatial grouping by quality characteristics
- Missing visual alerts for critical issues (circular dependencies, God Classes)

**User impact:**
Without effective visualization, users with large codebases (100+ files) struggle to:
- Quickly identify refactoring priorities
- Understand architectural health at a glance
- Communicate technical debt to stakeholders
- Track quality improvements over time

## Proposed Solution

**Enhance the existing D3.js visualization with multi-layered visual encoding** that transforms raw metrics into an intuitive, interactive quality dashboard.

### Core Visualization Components

#### 1. Quality-Encoded Dependency Graph (Primary View)

**Visual Design - Dual Encoding System:**

| Attribute | Visual Encoding | Scale |
|-----------|-----------------|-------|
| **Complexity** | Node fill shade (light â†’ dark) | Darker = higher cognitive complexity |
| **Code Smells** | Border color (gray â†’ red) | Redder = worse smell severity |
| **Lines of Code** | Node size | Larger = more LOC |
| **Instability** | Border style | Dashed = unstable (>0.7) |

**Complexity Shading (Node Fill):**
```
Low Complexity (0-5)    â†’ Light gray   (#f3f4f6)
Moderate (6-10)         â†’ Medium gray  (#9ca3af)  
High (11-20)            â†’ Dark gray    (#4b5563)
Very High (21-30)       â†’ Charcoal     (#1f2937)
Critical (31+)          â†’ Near black   (#111827)
```

**Code Smell Borders (Severity-Based Red Scale):**
```
No smells               â†’ No border or thin gray (#e5e7eb, 1px)
Info-level smells       â†’ Light red border (#fca5a5, 2px)
Warning-level smells    â†’ Medium red border (#f87171, 3px)
Error-level smells      â†’ Bright red border (#ef4444, 4px)
Multiple error smells   â†’ Dark red border (#dc2626, 5px) + glow effect
```

**Combined Visual Effect:**
- A file with high complexity AND bad smells = dark node + thick red border (immediate attention)
- A file with low complexity AND no smells = light node + no border (healthy)
- A file with high complexity BUT no smells = dark node + no border (complex but clean)
- A file with low complexity BUT bad smells = light node + red border (style issues)

**Edges represent dependencies** with strength encoding:
- **Thickness**: Coupling strength (1-5px based on dependency count)
- **Color**: Normal=#64748b (gray), Circular=#dc2626 (red) with animated pulse
- **Opacity**: 0.3-0.8 based on dependency weight

**Special visual indicators:**
- **Glowing red halo**: Files with error-level code smells (pulsing animation)
- **Warning badges**: Icon overlays (God Class ðŸ‘‘, Long Method ðŸ“, Deep Nesting ðŸ”½)
- **Pulsing animation**: Nodes involved in circular dependencies
- **Cluster boundaries**: Semi-transparent hulls grouping by module/package

#### 2. Quality Distribution Dashboard (Secondary View)

| Panel | Type | Purpose |
|-------|------|---------|
| Complexity Heat Map | Treemap | Show complexity distribution across packages (grayscale) |
| Code Smell Breakdown | Stacked Bar | Aggregate smells by severity per file/module (red scale) |
| Coupling vs. Cohesion | Scatter Plot | Identify architectural outliers (danger zones) |
| Health Score Gauge | Radial Arc | Display overall project health (0-100) |

#### 3. Interactive Features

- **Filter Controls**: Complexity threshold slider, smell severity checkboxes, module selector
- **Navigation**: Zoom/pan with minimap, search with fuzzy matching
- **Tooltips**: Rich hover cards with metrics, recommendations, action buttons
- **Responsive**: LOD for large codebases, module aggregation for >200 files

## Visual Mockups

### Main Quality Graph - Visual Encoding
```

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
 High Complexity    â”‚  â— (dark/none)  â”‚  [â—] (dark/red)
                    â”‚  "Simplify"     â”‚  "Critical"
```

## User Stories

| Role | Need | Benefit |
|------|------|---------|
| **Technical Lead** | See complexity (shade) AND smells (red) at a glance | Prioritize by dual concern |
| **Engineer** | Identify files with red borders | Fix code smells quickly |
| **Product Manager** | Explain "dark + red = bad" visually | Clear stakeholder communication |
| **New Team Member** | Understand visual encoding quickly | Intuitive learning curve |

## Technical Approach

### Data Flow
```
Analysis Engine â†’ JSON Export â†’ D3.js Rendering â†’ Interactive Dashboard
     â”‚                â”‚                â”‚                  â”‚
 Metrics          Graph data       Visual encoding    User interaction
```

### D3.js Color Scales
```javascript
// Complexity scale (grayscale - darker = more complex)
const complexityScale = d3.scaleLinear()
  .domain([0, 10, 20, 30, 50])
  .range(['#f3f4f6', '#9ca3af', '#4b5563', '#1f2937', '#111827']);

// Smell severity scale (red - redder = worse)
const smellSeverityScale = d3.scaleOrdinal()
  .domain(['none', 'info', 'warning', 'error', 'critical'])
  .range(['#e5e7eb', '#fca5a5', '#f87171', '#ef4444', '#dc2626']);

// Border width based on smell count/severity
const borderWidthScale = d3.scaleLinear()
  .domain([0, 1, 3, 5, 10])
  .range([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]);
```

### Implementation Phases

| Phase | Duration | Deliverables |
|-------|----------|--------------|
| 1. Core Graph | Week 1-2 | Force layout, **complexity shading**, **red smell borders**, basic tooltips |
| 2. Enhanced Encoding | Week 3 | Edge styling, animations, cluster hulls, badges |
| 3. Dashboard Panels | Week 4 | Heat map (grayscale), smell chart (red), scatter plot, gauge |
| 4. Interactivity | Week 5 | Filters, search, focus mode, rich tooltips |
| 5. Polish | Week 6 | LOD, aggregation, responsive, accessibility |

## Acceptance Criteria

### Visual Encoding (Updated)
- [ ] **Complexity shading**: Node fill uses grayscale (light=low â†’ dark=high complexity)
- [ ] **Smell borders**: Node border uses red scale (gray=none â†’ dark red=critical smells)
- [ ] **Border width**: Thicker borders for more/worse smells (1-5px)
- [ ] **Combined encoding**: Both attributes visible simultaneously on each node
- [ ] Node size encodes LOC (perceptually linear)
- [ ] Edge thickness encodes coupling strength
- [ ] Circular dependencies visually distinct (pulsing red animation)
- [ ] Glow effect on nodes with error-level smells

### Interactive Features
- [ ] Zoom and pan without performance degradation
- [ ] Filters update visualization in <1 second
- [ ] Tooltips appear on hover with complete metrics
- [ ] Click to focus/expand modules
- [ ] Search highlights matching files
- [ ] Filter by complexity threshold (slider)
- [ ] Filter by smell severity (checkboxes)

### Performance
- [ ] Render <50 files in <1 second
- [ ] Render 50-200 files in <3 seconds
- [ ] Render >200 files with aggregation in <5 seconds
- [ ] Smooth animations (60 fps)

### Accessibility
- [ ] Keyboard navigation for all interactive elements
- [ ] ARIA labels for screen readers
- [ ] Alternative patterns for color-blind users (shape + pattern options)
- [ ] Sufficient contrast (WCAG AA)

## Priority & Effort (RICE)

| Factor | Value | Rationale |
|--------|-------|-----------|
| **Reach** | 500 users/year | All users running analysis reports |
| **Impact** | High (2.0) | Dual encoding (shade + border) provides immediate insight |
| **Confidence** | 80% | Proven D3 technology, existing foundation |
| **Effort** | 6 weeks | 1 developer full-time |

**RICE Score: 133** â†’ **Prioritize for next sprint**

## Dependencies

- **Requires**: v0.21.0 analysis capabilities (âœ… Complete)
- **Blocks**: Real-time analysis updates, historical trend tracking

## Subtasks

- [ ] #52 Phase 1: Core graph with complexity shading and smell borders
- [ ] #53 Phase 2: Edge styling and animations
- [ ] #54 Phase 3: Dashboard panels
- [ ] #55 Phase 4: Interactive filters and tooltips
- [ ] #56 Phase 5: Performance optimization and polish

## Milestone
v0.22.0 - Enhanced Visualization

issues.title: Add "analyze" intent path to LLM controller with dedicated structural analysis prompt
issues.body:
## Summary

Add "analyze" as a third intent path in the LLM controller, alongside the existing "find" (search) and "answer" (QA) paths. This enables users to ask structural analysis questions through the chat interface and receive intelligent interpretations of code quality metrics.

## Problem Statement

Currently, the LLM controller supports two intent types:
- **"find"** â†’ Generates search queries, ranks results
- **"answer"** â†’ Uses tool calling to gather context and answer questions

Users who want to ask questions like "What are the most complex functions?" or "Show me coupling issues" must use the CLI directly. By adding an "analyze" intent, we enable natural language queries about code structure and quality with LLM-powered interpretation.

## Proposed Implementation

### 1. Extend Intent Detection

Modify `IntentType` in `llm_client.py`:
```python
IntentType = Literal["find", "answer", "analyze"]
```

Update intent detection prompt to recognize analysis queries:
- Complexity questions ("what's complex", "cognitive complexity")
- Quality questions ("code smells", "quality issues")  
- Coupling questions ("dependencies", "coupling", "circular")
- Trend questions ("getting worse", "improving")

### 2. Create `run_chat_analyze()` Function

New function in `llm_client.py` that:
1. Parses the user's analysis question
2. Determines which metrics/tools to invoke
3. Calls analysis tools (from #37)
4. Passes results to LLM with specialized prompt
5. Returns interpreted insights

### 3. Dedicated Analysis Prompt

Create a specialized prompt template for structural analysis that:
- Understands metric thresholds and their meanings
- Can grade code quality (A-F scale)
- Provides actionable recommendations
- Prioritizes issues by severity and remediation effort
- Uses consistent terminology aligned with industry standards

**Prompt sections**:
- System context (what metrics mean, threshold definitions)
- Grading rubric (complexity, coupling, cohesion scales)
- Output format (structured insights with recommendations)
- Code smell interpretation guide

### 4. Analysis Tool Integration

The analyze path will have access to these tools (from #37):
- `analyze_project()` - Project-wide metrics summary
- `analyze_file(path)` - File-level detailed analysis
- `find_smells(type?, severity?)` - Code smell detection
- `get_complexity_hotspots(limit)` - Top N complex functions
- `check_circular_dependencies()` - Dependency cycle detection
- `get_metric_trends(metric, period)` - Historical comparison

### 5. Query Type Classification

The analysis prompt should handle different query types:

| Query Type | Example | Tools Used |
|------------|---------|------------|
| Overview | "How healthy is this codebase?" | `analyze_project()` |
| Specific | "Analyze auth.py complexity" | `analyze_file()` |
| Discovery | "Find the worst code smells" | `find_smells()` |
| Comparison | "Is complexity getting worse?" | `get_metric_trends()` |
| Targeted | "Show circular dependencies" | `check_circular_dependencies()` |

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] IntentType extended to include "analyze"
- [ ] Intent detection prompt updated to recognize analysis queries
- [ ] `run_chat_analyze()` function implemented
- [ ] Dedicated analysis prompt template created with:
  - [ ] Metric threshold definitions
  - [ ] Grading rubric (A-F scale)
  - [ ] Code smell interpretation guide
  - [ ] Recommendation templates
- [ ] Router in `chat.py` updated to dispatch to analyze path
- [ ] Analysis tools (#37) integrated into analyze flow
- [ ] Streaming output support for analysis responses
- [ ] Unit tests for intent detection (analyze queries)
- [ ] Integration tests for analyze path end-to-end
- [ ] Documentation for analysis query examples

## Dependencies

**Must be completed first**:
- #10 - Create analyze --quick CLI command (provides underlying analysis)
- #37 - Expose analysis as MCP tools (provides tool interface)
- #38 - Expose analysis results to LLM for intelligent interpretation (provides schema)

**Blocked by**: #10, #37, #38

## Technical Notes

### Router Update (chat.py)

```python
async def run_chat_with_intent(client: LLMClient, message: str, ...):
    intent = await client.detect_intent(message)
    
    if intent == "find":
        return await run_chat_search(client, message, ...)
    elif intent == "answer":
        return await run_chat_answer(client, message, ...)
    elif intent == "analyze":
        return await run_chat_analyze(client, message, ...)  # NEW
```

### Example Interactions

**User**: "What's the cognitive complexity of the indexer module?"
**System** (analyze path):
1. Detects "analyze" intent
2. Calls `analyze_file("core/indexer.py")`
3. LLM interprets: "The indexer module has a cognitive complexity of 47 (Grade: C). The `_process_file()` function is the main contributor at 23. Consider extracting the nested loops into helper functions."

**User**: "Are there any code smells I should worry about?"
**System** (analyze path):
1. Detects "analyze" intent  
2. Calls `find_smells(severity="high")`
3. LLM interprets: "Found 3 high-severity code smells: 2 God Classes in services/ and 1 Long Method in utils/parser.py. I recommend starting with the Long Method as it has the lowest refactoring effort."

## Milestone

v0.21.0 - Search Integration

This is the **final ticket** in Phase 5, representing the culmination of the structural analysis feature set with full LLM integration.

issues.title: Expose analysis results to LLM for intelligent interpretation
issues.body:
## Description
Expose the structural analysis API and its generated data to LLM controllers (Claude, GPT, etc.) so they can intelligently interpret analysis results for users.

## Motivation
Raw metrics like "cognitive complexity: 23" or "efferent coupling: 15" are meaningless to most developers. By exposing structured analysis data to LLMs, we enable:

1. **Natural language explanations**: "This function is complex because it has 5 nested conditionals handling edge cases"
2. **Actionable recommendations**: "Consider extracting the validation logic into a separate function"
3. **Contextual insights**: "This file has high coupling because it's a facade that orchestrates multiple services"
4. **Priority guidance**: "Focus on `auth_handler.py` firstâ€”it has the highest debt score and blocks 3 other modules"

## Implementation

### 1. Structured CLI Output
The `analyze` command outputs machine-readable structured data:

```bash
# JSON output for LLM consumption
mcp-vector-search analyze --output json

# Include semantic context for LLM interpretation
mcp-vector-search analyze --output json --include-context
```

### 2. Analysis Schema for LLMs
Define a schema that includes:
- Raw metrics (complexity scores, coupling counts)
- Threshold comparisons (above/below, by how much)
- Smell classifications with severity
- Remediation time estimates
- Related code locations

```json
{
  "analysis_type": "function",
  "name": "validate_token",
  "file": "src/auth/handler.py",
  "metrics": {
    "cognitive_complexity": {
      "score": 23,
      "threshold": 15,
      "grade": "D",
      "exceeds_by": 8,
      "interpretation": "significantly_complex"
    }
  },
  "smells": [
    {
      "type": "long_method",
      "severity": "warning",
      "details": "67 lines (threshold: 30)",
      "remediation_minutes": 20
    }
  ],
  "context": {
    "called_by": ["login_handler", "refresh_token"],
    "calls": ["decode_jwt", "check_expiry", "validate_claims"],
    "purpose_hint": "JWT token validation with multiple claim checks"
  }
}
```

### 3. MCP Tool: `interpret_analysis`
New MCP tool that accepts analysis results and returns LLM-friendly interpretation:

```python
@mcp_tool
async def interpret_analysis(
    analysis_json: str,
    focus: str = "summary",  # summary | recommendations | priorities
    verbosity: str = "normal"  # brief | normal | detailed
) -> str:
    """
    Interpret structural analysis results in natural language.
    
    Args:
        analysis_json: JSON output from 'analyze' command
        focus: What aspect to focus on
        verbosity: How detailed the explanation should be
    
    Returns:
        Natural language interpretation of the analysis
    """
```

### 4. Prompt Templates
Include prompt templates that help LLMs interpret results:

```markdown
## Analysis Interpretation Guide

When interpreting structural analysis results:

1. **Cognitive Complexity**
   - A (â‰¤5): Easy to understand, no action needed
   - B (â‰¤10): Moderate, acceptable for most code
   - C (â‰¤15): Consider simplifying if frequently modified
   - D (â‰¤25): Should be refactored when touched
   - F (>25): Critical - split into smaller functions

2. **Code Smells**
   - Explain WHY it's a smell, not just what it is
   - Suggest specific refactoring patterns
   - Consider the code's context and purpose
...
```

## Tasks
- [ ] Add `--include-context` flag to analyze command
- [ ] Define JSON schema for LLM consumption
- [ ] Add semantic context to analysis output (callers, callees, purpose hints)
- [ ] Create `interpret_analysis` MCP tool
- [ ] Add prompt templates for analysis interpretation
- [ ] Create examples of LLM-interpreted analysis
- [ ] Document the LLM integration in user guide

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `analyze --output json --include-context` produces LLM-consumable output
- [ ] MCP tool `interpret_analysis` returns natural language explanations
- [ ] Claude/GPT can explain "why" a function is complex, not just "that" it is
- [ ] Recommendations are actionable and context-aware
- [ ] Documentation explains how to use LLM interpretation

## Dependencies
**Blocked by:** #10 (analyze CLI), #14 (code smells), #29 (JSON exporter), #37 (MCP tools)
**Blocks:** None (final feature in pipeline)

## Related Epic
Part of Epic #34: Search Integration - Phase 5

## References
- Design Doc: Visualization Export section
- MCP Tool exposure patterns from existing tools

issues.title: Implement quality-aware ranking
issues.body:
## Description
Blend semantic relevance with quality metrics for search result ranking.

## Tasks
- [ ] Define quality score formula:
  - Base: complexity_grade (A=100, B=80, C=60, D=40, F=20)
  - Penalty: -10 per code smell
  - Bonus: +20 if no smells
- [ ] Add `--quality-weight W` flag (default 0.3)
- [ ] Calculate combined score: `(1-W) Ã— relevance + W Ã— quality`
- [ ] Re-rank search results by combined score
- [ ] Show quality indicators in results
- [ ] Add quality explanation to result details

## Acceptance Criteria
- Default `--quality-weight 0.3` balances relevance and quality
- High-quality results boosted in rankings
- Very low-quality results deprioritized (even if relevant)
- Quality weight 0.0 = pure semantic search (backward compatible)
- Quality weight 1.0 = pure quality ranking

## Ranking Example
```
Query: 'authentication handler'

Result 1: auth/handler.py:validate_token() [Relevance: 0.95, Quality: 100, Combined: 0.96]
  âœ“ Grade A, No smells

Result 2: auth/legacy.py:authenticate() [Relevance: 0.98, Quality: 20, Combined: 0.75]
  âœ— Grade F, 3 smells (long_method, deep_nesting, high_complexity)
```

issues.title: Implement Halstead metrics collector
issues.body:
## Description
Implement Tier 2 collector for Halstead complexity metrics.

## Tasks
- [ ] Create `HalsteadCollector` class extending `MetricCollector`
- [ ] Track operators and operands during traversal
- [ ] Calculate metrics:
  - n1 = unique operators
  - n2 = unique operands
  - N1 = total operators
  - N2 = total operands
  - Vocabulary = n1 + n2
  - Length = N1 + N2
  - Volume = Length Ã— log2(Vocabulary)
  - Difficulty = (n1/2) Ã— (N2/n2)
  - Effort = Volume Ã— Difficulty
- [ ] Return `HalsteadMetric` with all values
- [ ] Add to file metrics

## Acceptance Criteria
- Correct calculation for all test cases
- Threshold: Difficulty â‰¤ 30
- Performance: <2ms per file
- Correlates with bug density in sample codebases

## Operator Examples
Python: +, -, *, /, =, ==, if, for, def, return, import
JavaScript: +, -, *, /, =, ==, ===, if, for, function, return

## Operand Examples
Variables, constants, function names, literals

## Test Cases
- Simple function (low difficulty)
- Complex function with many operators (high difficulty)
- Verify Volume and Difficulty calculations

issues.title: Implement LCOM4 cohesion metric
issues.body:
## Description
Implement Tier 3 collector for class cohesion analysis using LCOM4.

## Tasks
- [ ] Create `CohesionCollector` class extending `MetricCollector`
- [ ] Build method-variable access graph for each class
- [ ] Nodes = methods, edges connect methods that:
  - Share instance variables, OR
  - Call each other
- [ ] Use union-find or DFS to count connected components
- [ ] Exclude constructors and empty methods
- [ ] Calculate LCOM4 = number of connected components
- [ ] Return `CohesionMetric` with LCOM4, connected_components, shared_variables

## Acceptance Criteria
- Correct LCOM4 calculation for all test cases
- Threshold: LCOM4 = 1 (ideal), â‰¤ 2 (acceptable)
- Performance: ~5ms per class
- Memory: ~1KB per class
- Works with Python, JavaScript, TypeScript classes

## Test Cases
- Cohesive class (LCOM4=1): all methods share variables
- Non-cohesive class (LCOM4=2): two method groups, no overlap
- God class (LCOM4â‰¥3): multiple unrelated responsibilities
- Class with only constructors (LCOM4=1)

## Interpretation
- LCOM4 = 1: Class is cohesive (good)
- LCOM4 = 2: Class has 2 responsibilities (consider splitting)
- LCOM4 â‰¥ 3: Class is a god class (refactor required)

## Related Epic
Part of Epic #3: Cross-File Analysis - Phase 3

## References
- Design Doc Section: LCOM4 (Lack of Cohesion of Methods)\n\n## Dependencies\n\n**Blocked by:** #2, #8

issues.title: Create SQLite metrics store
issues.body:
## Description
Implement SQLite database for storing aggregated metrics and historical snapshots.

## Tasks
- [ ] Create `analysis/storage/metrics_db.py` module
- [ ] Implement `MetricsDatabase` class
- [ ] Create schema with tables:
  - `file_metrics`: file-level metrics (current snapshot)
  - `project_snapshots`: project-wide metrics over time
  - `code_smells`: individual smell instances
  - `circular_dependencies`: detected cycles
- [ ] Add indexes on key fields (file_path, language, complexity)
- [ ] Implement CRUD operations for each table
- [ ] Add migration support for schema updates
- [ ] Store database in `.mcp-vector-search/metrics.db`

## Schema
```sql
CREATE TABLE file_metrics (
    file_path TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
    language TEXT,
    total_lines INTEGER,
    code_lines INTEGER,
    cognitive_complexity_total INTEGER,
    cognitive_complexity_max INTEGER,
    efferent_coupling INTEGER,
    afferent_coupling INTEGER,
    instability REAL,
    indexed_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
);

CREATE TABLE project_snapshots (
    id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
    snapshot_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    total_files INTEGER,
    total_lines INTEGER,
    avg_cognitive_complexity REAL,
    total_smells INTEGER,
    circular_dependency_count INTEGER,
    estimated_debt_hours REAL
);

CREATE TABLE code_smells (
    id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
    file_path TEXT,
    start_line INTEGER,
    end_line INTEGER,
    smell_type TEXT,
    severity TEXT,
    message TEXT,
    detected_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
);

CREATE TABLE circular_dependencies (
    id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
    cycle_hash TEXT UNIQUE,
    cycle_files TEXT,  -- JSON array
    file_count INTEGER,
    detected_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
);
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- Database created on first run
- All CRUD operations work
- Indexes improve query performance
- Schema migrations tested
- Concurrent access handled safely

## Related Epic
Part of Epic #3: Cross-File Analysis - Phase 3

## References
- Design Doc Section: SQLite Metrics Store\n\n## Dependencies\n\n**Blocked by:** #2\n**Blocks:** #25, #32, #33

issues.title: Implement circular dependency detection
issues.body:
## Description
Detect circular dependencies using Tarjan's SCC algorithm on import graph.

## Tasks
- [ ] Implement Tarjan's strongly connected components algorithm
- [ ] Build directed graph from import relationships
- [ ] Detect all cycles in the import graph
- [ ] Categorize cycles:
  - 2-file cycles: file_a â†’ file_b â†’ file_a
  - 3+ file cycles: file_a â†’ file_b â†’ file_c â†’ file_a
- [ ] Create `CircularDependency` dataclass with cycle path and severity
- [ ] Store in SQLite circular_dependencies table
- [ ] Add to console reporter (show cycle paths)
- [ ] Mark as 'error' if > 2 files, 'warning' if 2 files

## Acceptance Criteria
- Detects all cycles correctly
- No false positives
- Handles self-imports
- Performance: O(V + E) where V=files, E=imports
- Output shows clear cycle path: A â†’ B â†’ C â†’ A

## Test Cases
- Project with no cycles (count=0)
- Simple 2-file cycle (A imports B, B imports A)
- Complex 4-file cycle
- Multiple independent cycles
- Self-import (file imports itself)

## Related Epic
Part of Epic #3: Cross-File Analysis - Phase 3

## References
- Design Doc Section: Circular Dependencies\n\n## Dependencies\n\n**Blocked by:** #20

issues.title: Calculate Instability Index
issues.body:
## Description
Calculate instability metric I = Ce / (Ca + Ce) for architectural analysis.

## Tasks
- [ ] Implement instability calculation: I = Ce / (Ca + Ce)
- [ ] Handle edge case: Ca + Ce = 0 (I = 0.5 or undefined?)
- [ ] Add instability to FileMetrics
- [ ] Calculate project-wide average instability
- [ ] Identify most stable files (I â†’ 0)
- [ ] Identify most unstable files (I â†’ 1)
- [ ] Add to console reporter and JSON export

## Acceptance Criteria
- Correct calculation for all files
- I âˆˆ [0, 1] range
- Edge cases handled gracefully
- Interpretation documented:
  - I = 0: Completely stable (dependencies flow in, none flow out)
  - I = 1: Completely unstable (dependencies flow out, none flow in)
  - I â‰ˆ 0.5: Balanced

## Interpretation Examples
- Utility module: Ca=20, Ce=2 â†’ I=0.09 (stable, good)
- Application entry point: Ca=0, Ce=15 â†’ I=1.0 (unstable, expected)
- God module: Ca=30, Ce=25 â†’ I=0.45 (balanced but concerning)

## Description

## Tasks
- [ ] Create `analysis/collectors/smells.py` module

  - `long_method`: LOC > 30 OR cognitive_complexity > 15
  - `deep_nesting`: max_depth > 4
  - `long_parameter_list`: param_count > 5
  - `god_class`: methods > 20 AND loc > 500
  - `large_class`: LOC > 500
  - `empty_catch`: catch block with pass/empty body
  - `magic_numbers`: numeric literals outside [-1, 0, 1, 2, 10, 100]
- [ ] Assign confidence levels (High/Medium)

- [ ] Store smells in `CodeSmell` dataclass with location info
- [ ] Add smell counts to chunk and file metrics

## Acceptance Criteria
- All documented smells detected correctly
- False positive rate < 5% on sample codebases
- Smells include file path, line range, type, severity, message
- Can disable specific smells via config
- Performance: <2ms per file

## Test Cases
- Detect long method (70 lines)
- Detect deep nesting (6 levels)
- Detect long parameter list (8 params)
- Detect god class (30 methods, 600 lines)
- Detect empty catch block
- Detect magic numbers (except whitelisted)

- [ ] Return parameter count in metadata

## Acceptance Criteria
- Correct count for all parameter types
- Threshold: â‰¤5 parameters (warning)
- Works with default parameters, rest parameters, destructured parameters
- Performance: O(1) per function

## Test Cases
- Function with no parameters
- Function with 3 positional parameters
- Function with 7 parameters (exceeds threshold)
- Function with default values and *args/**kwargs

## Related Epic
Part of Epic #1: Core Metrics - Phase 1\n\n## Dependencies\n\n**Blocked by:** #2\n**Blocks:** #8

issues.title: Implement Nesting Depth Collector
issues.body:
## Description
Implement Tier 1 collector tracking maximum nesting depth in functions.

## Tasks
- [ ] Create `NestingDepthCollector` class extending `MetricCollector`
- [ ] Track current nesting depth during traversal
- [ ] Record maximum depth reached
- [ ] Capture deepest location (start_line, end_line)
- [ ] Return `NestingDepthMetric` with max_depth and location

## Acceptance Criteria
- Correctly tracks nesting across all control structures
- Identifies deepest nesting location in code
- Threshold: â‰¤4 levels (configurable)
- Performance: <0.5ms per 1000 LOC

## Test Cases
- Flat function (depth=0)
- Single if statement (depth=1)
- 6 levels of nested if statements (depth=6)

## Related Epic
Part of Epic #1: Core Metrics - Phase 1\n\n## Dependencies\n\n**Blocked by:** #2\n**Blocks:** #8

issues.title: Implement Cyclomatic Complexity Collector
issues.body:
## Description
Implement Tier 1 collector counting linearly independent paths through code.

## Tasks
- [ ] Create `CyclomaticComplexityCollector` class extending `MetricCollector`
- [ ] Implement calculation: 1 + count(if, elif, for, while, case, catch, and, or, ternary)
- [ ] Track complexity per function
- [ ] Support Python, JavaScript, TypeScript syntax
- [ ] Return cyclomatic complexity score in `finalize_function()`

## Acceptance Criteria
- Correct calculation for all control flow nodes
- Handles edge cases (empty functions, nested structures)
- Performance: <1ms per 1000 LOC
- Memory overhead: ~50 bytes/function

## Test Cases
- Empty function (CC=1)
- Function with 10 sequential if statements (CC=11)
- Function with 4 nested if statements (CC=5)
- Switch/match statements with multiple cases

## Notes
This is a secondary metric to cognitive complexity. Used for comparison and completeness but not for quality gates.

## Related Epic
Part of Epic #1: Core Metrics - Phase 1

## References
- Design Doc Section: Cyclomatic Complexity\n\n## Dependencies\n\n**Blocked by:** #2\n**Blocks:** #8

issues.title: Implement Cognitive Complexity Collector
issues.body:
## Description
Implement Tier 1 collector using SonarQube's cognitive complexity algorithm with nesting penalties.

## Tasks
- [ ] Create `CognitiveComplexityCollector` class extending `MetricCollector`
- [ ] Define `COMPLEXITY_NODES` set (if, elif, else, for, while, try, catch, match, ternary, and, or)
- [ ] Define `NESTING_NODES` set for nesting penalty calculation
- [ ] Implement `collect_node()` to track complexity increments and nesting depth
- [ ] Implement nesting penalty: +1 additional per nesting level for control structures
- [ ] Implement `finalize_function()` to return complexity score and breakdown
- [ ] Track complexity breakdown by category (conditionals, loops, error_handling, boolean_operators)
- [ ] Compute complexity grade (A-F) based on thresholds

## Acceptance Criteria
- Algorithm matches SonarQube specification
- Handles Python, JavaScript, and TypeScript correctly
- Nesting penalty correctly applied
- Returns breakdown dict for visualization
- Performance: <1ms per 1000 LOC

## Test Cases
- Simple function (CC=0)
- Single if statement (CC=1)
- Nested if with penalty (CC=3)
- Boolean operators (CC=2 for 'and'/'or')
- Complex real-world validation function (CC=7)

## Related Epic
Part of Epic #1: Core Metrics - Phase 1

## References
- Design Doc Section: Cognitive Complexity
- SonarQube Cognitive Complexity Whitepaper\n\n## Dependencies\n\n**Blocked by:** #2\n**Blocks:** #8

issues.title: Create metric dataclasses and interfaces
issues.body:
## Description
Define the core data structures and abstract base classes for the metrics collection system.

## Tasks
- [ ] Create `ChunkMetrics` dataclass with Tier 1 fields (cognitive_complexity, cyclomatic_complexity, max_nesting_depth, line_count, parameter_count, method_count)
- [ ] Create `FileMetrics` dataclass for file-level aggregations
- [ ] Create `ProjectMetrics` dataclass for project-wide aggregations
- [ ] Create `MetricCollector` abstract base class with interface methods:
  - `collect_node(node, context, depth)`
  - `finalize_function(function_node, context)`
  - `finalize_file(context)`
  - `reset()`
- [ ] Create `CollectorContext` dataclass for passing context during traversal
- [ ] Add type hints and docstrings to all classes

## Acceptance Criteria
- All dataclasses properly defined with type hints
- Abstract base class follows LSP principles
- Documentation explains the collector lifecycle
- Unit tests verify dataclass serialization

## Related Epic
Part of Epic #1: Core Metrics - Phase 1

## References
- Design Doc Section: Data Model Extensions
- Design Doc Section: Collector Interface\n\n## Dependencies\n\n**Blocked by:** None (can start immediately)\n**Blocks:** #3, #4, #5, #6, #7, #8, #9

issues.title: [EPIC 1] Core Metrics - Phase 1
issues.body:
# Epic 1: Core Metrics (Phase 1)

**Timeline**: Week 1-2

## Description
Tier 1 collectors integrated into indexer with basic analysis command.

## Deliverables
- Tier 1 collectors integrated into indexer
- Extended chunk metadata in ChromaDB
- `analyze --quick` command
- Basic console reporter

## Validation Criteria
- Metrics match SonarQube on sample projects
- <10ms overhead per 1000 LOC

## Related Issues
This epic tracks the following implementation issues:
1. Create metric dataclasses and interfaces
2. Implement Cognitive Complexity Collector
3. Implement Cyclomatic Complexity Collector
4. Implement Nesting Depth Collector
5. Implement Parameter Count Collector
6. Implement Method Count Collector
7. Integrate collectors with existing TreeSitter indexer
8. Extend ChromaDB metadata schema
9. Create `analyze --quick` CLI command
10. Implement console reporter

## References
- Design Document: docs/research/mcp-vector-search-structural-analysis-design.md
- SonarQube Cognitive Complexity Whitepaper
